divs: sighting detailsas ufo sightings go, this is really a pathetic story, perhaps not worth mentioning, especially after all these years. but just in case you have other sightings mentioned in your records in or around that area during that time, i guess i should officially let someone know. in the early fifties, we lived about two miles west and one mile south of onsted, michigan, a very small village tucked into what is called the "irish hills" district, of lenawee county, about 15 miles from adrian, the county seat. there is nothing out there but farms - dirt roads, fields, hilly pastures and woods, plus numerous small natural lakes left behind from the last ice age. the nearest city is 15 miles away and there has never been, to my knowledge, any kind of government or military facility anywhere nearby. there is currently a very small airport at the edge of the village, but it was not built until sometime in the sixties, or maybe even the early seventies. but at any rate, at the time it was just pastures and it was miles the other way from where i saw my ufo. i was a little girl, 10 to 12 years old and would spend hours gazing at the stars, just aching to know what was out there. my family had all gone to bed, probably around 9:00 or 10:00, but as was my habit, i was wide awake, kneeling on the floor at a window with my elbows on the sill, staring up at the sky. slowly a yellow\greenish light appeared high to my left, coming in from the east headed west and going down at about a 45 degree angle. it was moving quite slowly, and i watched it for perhaps five seconds before it disappeared from my sight because of the nearby trees on the edge of our yard. we lived on a dirt road called brooks hwy., south of slee road, so this light crossed high in front of me and went down to the west of that road. there was no sound. i got up off the floor and went to my parents' room - i think they were still awake - and i told my dad what i had seen. he calmly but quickly pulled on his pants and the two of us went out into the yard. he was the kind of father who always believed me, no matter what. but of course, by then there was nothing to see. where ever the thing had landed, if it did land, was probably at least a quarter mile away with hills and hundreds of trees in between. i don't remmber what month it was, but it was warm enough to go out without a sweater, and there were green leaves on the trees. i feel like it was perhaps mid or late spring, but i'm not sure. so that's it. pitiful story. i don't know what it was, but i do know it was not a plane, a star, a shooting star or a comet - it was moving too slowly. the only thing it could have been at that time and that place and moving as it did, was a helicopter or a ufo. and what would a helicoper be doing in the farmlands outside onsted, michigan in 1950, 1951 or 1952 at 9:00 or 10:00 at night? as strange as it sounds, i could sooner believe it was a space ship with little green men before i could believe there would be a helicopter out there. i know we had helicopters that were being used in korea at the time, but i had never seen one in person, and that explanation never crossed my mind at the time ... but again, what would one be doing out there in rural america? i'm sorry if this is a waste of your time, but maybe someone else saw something back then and you already know about it. i don't think i want to know if it was just a helicopter - i've always been pleased that i saw something and i've pretended all these years that it was, in fact, a real honest to goodness ufo. and i am a believer. i've just not yet been lucky enough to really see anything important - well, actually i did see a model of russia's sputnik in their pavillion at the brussel's world fair in 1958. i was an exchange student at the time. i'm 66 years old now, but maybe someday.........in the meantime, i faithfully watch all the ufo programs on the history channel and long to know what it's all about, and wish i lived near a "hot spot". i'm glad there is an organization that takes this stuff seriously and people who are willing to come forward with their stories. thank you.
Summary: In the early 50s a yellow/greenish light dropped slowly from high in the east to the west at a 45 degree angle
